JSON data structure is below:
```{

    "email": "<mailto:useremail@gmail.com|useremail@gmail.com>",
    "password": "password"
}```

text: A of the my friends  advised me to document each step of my project in a clear language, as assembling and writing them all during the project presentation can be time-consuming. I am trying to follow this advice by documenting my progress, and in the end, compiling these notes to create an excellent technical project document. This way, we can have a well-structured document that summarizes the entire project efficiently.

text:
And if you want to test if you can get user information by id, you can use this endpoint: <http://localhost:8080/user/{id}>

A couple of notes:
• for testing, you'd have to wait until I commit my changes to main and then I think you'd have to put a user in your own local database and use their id in the endpoint to see if you actually get data back, I think. 
• Right now it's returning the password, too, but we would need to fix that later

text:
<@U055S98U8G2> I have some questions around best practices when using Spring Boot REST and React.  Specifically, I am working on the backend for user creation and login, and I am reviewing several videos and resources to understand how this works and I am seeing consistently that coders use the following:
• UserService class that handles business logic instead of writing all of the methods within the UserController. 
• a corresponding UserServiceInterface that the UserService class references 
• and then finally the expected UserController that has the PostMapping methods, but these methods receive data from the frontend, but then call the UserService class to process the data
My questions around this are:
1. The information held in the Service Interface is often defining things like findAll, findById, save, update and deleteById methods, but aren't those built into the CRUD repository library we import? So do we really need that? What purpose would it have?
2. I could see the benefit of using a separate Service class to keep the Controller "skinny", but is that best practice? a personal preference? an organizational preference? What would you recommend we do for our project? 
_cc <@U056Y707Y14> because I think she had a lot of the same questions._

I hope this is enough for you to get started on your stuff. let me know if you have any questions or run into any issues!
